Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Rich Multimedia Experience in Emerging Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A cognitive radio (CR) is a frequency-agile wireless communication device with intelligent control and a monitoring interface that enables dynamic spectrum access. The CR concept represents a paradigm change in spectrum regulation and utilization. As basic understandings gained, there is a compelling need to fully capitalize CR's high potential for supporting new applications.

This CAREER project investigates the problem of enabling rich multimedia services in emerging CR networks. Although highly rewarding, the new dimension of dynamics on channel availability, sensing, and access brings about a whole level of technical challenges. To address these challenges, a novel cross-layer optimization and control approach is employed, complemented with distributed algorithm design and development of an open source CR video testbed. The manifold design trade-offs, multifarious dynamics, scarce resources and, on the other hand, video's tight QoS constraints make the optimization and control approach highly suited for "squeezing" the most out of CR video networks. The three research thrusts include: cross-layer optimization of CR video networks, classical and modern control theory based analysis and design of CR video networks, and experimental research with a CR video testbed and field experiments.

This project will serve a critical need by enabling video communications in emerging CR networks for commercial and mission-critical applications. Open source software, a CR video testbed, and experimental data will be distributed in the wireless community. The research outcomes will be integrated with course development, textbook writing, involving graduate and undergraduate students in cutting-edge research, promoting diversity, and outreach to K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A cognitive radio (CR) is a frequency-agile wireless communication device with intelligent control and a monitoring interface that enables dynamic spectrum access. The CR concept represents a paradigm change in spectrum regulation and utilization. Its high potential has stimulated a flurry of exciting activities in engineering, economics, and regulatory communities in searching for better spectrum management policies and techniques. As basic understandings gained, we need to consider how to fully capitalize CR's high potential for enabling new applications in emerging CR networks.

Historically, CR has evolved from the physical layer (PHY), e.g., reconfiguring radios on the fly, to higher layers, e.g., network-wide situation awareness. Although we are approaching Shannon Limit in the PHY, there is still huge space for improvement in higher layers, especially in QoS provisioning for multimedia applications.  However, since efficient dynamic spectrum access has driven most of the CR research so far, this rich problem area has not been the primary concern in mainstream CR research.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, we investigated the challenging problem of enabling rich multimedia communications (specifically, video service as a reference application) in emerging CR networks. Although highly rewarding, this problem brings about a whole level of technical challenges.  The new dimension of dynamics on channel availability, sensing, and access makes it a tremendous task to deliver video data with stringent QoS requirements.  We investigated this important problem with a cross-layer optimization and control theoretic approach, complemented with distributed algorithm design and development of open source SCA-compliant CR video testbed and toolkit. The manifold design trade-offs, multifarious dynamics, limited resources and, on the other hand, video's tight QoS constraints make the proposed approach highly suited for squeezing the most out of CR video networks.

We have focused on the following three sets of problems and provided theoretic studies and effective solutions in this project.

(i) Cross-layer Optimization of CR Video Networks. We developed theoretical bounds and performance limits for CR video networks, with focus on exploring the trade-off between maximizing secondary user video quality and primary user protection, as well as the impact of sensing errors. In addition to a holistic analytical framework that allows the unification of the multi-dimensional cross-layer design space, we also developed effective distributed algorithms for practical CR video systems.

(ii) A Control-Theoretic Approach to CR Video Networks. We applied classic and modern control theory to solve problems in CR video networks, for developing theoretical models and stability criteria, gaining important understandings, and developing effective and robust controllers for CR video networks. We focused on important aspects including feedback control, scheduling and stability, and robustness under uncertainties for CR video networks in this research with effective congestion control mechanisms developed. 

(iii) Experimental Research. We also conducted extensive experimental studies of CR video networks, such as formalizing practical protocols, prototyping using open source programmable wireless platforms, developing CR performance evaluation methodologies, and field tests.

Broader Impacts: This research has served a critical need by enabling high quality video communications in emerging CR networks for many commercial and mission-critical applications, which benefited society as a whole.  Integration of research and education has been the major objective of this career project.  The PI has been greatly involved in the curriculum development for graduate education and Auburn's ABET-accredited Bachelor of Wireless Engineering program. A relatively large number of graduate and undergraduate students participated in this project, and gained not only substantial theoretical and experimental research experience, but also important career development skills for success beyond graduation. The PI is dedicated to promoting diversity in the wireless workforce. He advised many NSF REU students in the project years, including four females, one Hispanic, and three African-Americans, and mentored two NSF RET teachers, including one African-American. He also graduated one female PhD student. He also developed collaborations with Tuskegee University and Tennessee State University (two HBCUs) on research, curriculum development, and recruiting African-American graduate students.
